description:
Scatophagus argus, commonly known as the spotted scat or spotted butterfish, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Scatophagidae. It is found in the Indo-Pacific region, ranging from the eastern coast of Africa to the western Pacific Ocean.

Scatophagus argus is a small to medium-sized fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 30 cm. It has a laterally compressed, oval-shaped body with a distinctive pattern of dark spots or ocelli covering its body and fins. The fins are generally yellowish or orange in color.

This species is primarily found in coastal habitats, such as coral reefs, mangrove estuaries, and seagrass beds, where it feeds on a variety of small invertebrates and algae. Scatophagus argus is known to be a hardy and adaptable species, able to tolerate a wide range of environmental conditions, including fluctuations in salinity and temperature.

Scatophagus argus is of some commercial importance, being caught for food in parts of its range. It is also sometimes kept in aquariums due to its unique appearance and relatively peaceful behavior.
